Elucidating the reaction mechanism for large molecule like C3H8 species remains challenging, and the performances determined by metals’ sizes are still in heavily debate. In this work, we figured out the optimal C3H8 oxidation reaction pathway on Pt-CeO2 structure by density functional theory (DFT) calculations and microkinetic analysis, and revealed that O2 participating in C3H8 oxidation showed different paths with different Pt sizes. Microkinetic results further revealed that CH2CHOCH3* excessively occupying active sites dramatically limited C3H8 oxidation performance on Pt clusters, while the superior activity on Pt nanoparticles was attributed to rapid desorption of CO* at high temperatures. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Propane oxidation DFT calculation Microkinetic analysis Reaction route Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are main precursors for particulate matter and high concentration of ozone in the atmosphere [1–3], which seriously affect environment and health. Alkanes are the types of VOCs with stable chemical properties [4], which are mainly emitted from vehicles and petrochemical industries [5]. Propane has highly stable CH bonds which is often used as model molecule to evaluate the performance of catalysts for alkanes oxidation [6–8]. To this day, platinum group metals are still best-performing propane oxidation catalysts [9,10], in this work we focus on the propane oxidation reaction mechanisms with different particle sizes of Pt species on CeO2 (111) facet. In the past decades, single atom Pt catalysts attract widespread attention because of their highly atomic efficiency [11–14]. However, more studies reported that Pt cluster or nanoparticle in many applications exhibited better performances [15–18]. Guo et al. [19] concluded that the strong metal-support interactions (SMSI) and H-spillover effect were balanced on Ru clusters, which contributed to the best CO2 methanation activity. Lee et al. [17] claimed that Pt ensembles on CeO2 showed much better C3H6 and C3H8 oxidation performances than Pt single atoms, and the synergistic effect between neighboring Pt atoms was verified to change energy barrier and reaction paths, which caused CO2 hydrogenating into methanol and formic acid instead of entire methanol [15]. In previous work [20], we elucidated the propane oxidation mechanism on two adjacent Pt1 on CeO2 (110) facet, CO desorption and dissociation of adsorbed O2 are the rate-determining steps at low temperature and high temperature, respectively. Here, we will investigate the nature of propane oxidation process on Pt cluster and Pt nanoparticle on CeO2 (111) facet by DFT calculations and microkinetic analyses. Herein, the structures of Pt2 dimer and Pt13 ensemble individually adsorbing on CeO2 (111) were established to represent the catalyst models with active sites of Pt clusters and Pt nanoparticles, respectively. By density functional theory (DFT) calculations [21], the propane oxidation reaction steps were determined. Further, the optimal C3H8 oxidation reaction pathways were found by microkinetic analyses [22] which was conducted using the CATKINAS procedure [23], and the results revealed the rate-determining steps of C3H8 oxidation reaction and key intermediates which significantly affected activity. 2 Methods DFT calculations [24] were conducted on Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [25–28]. The exchange and correlation energies were processed using generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [29] form generated from projected augmented wave (PAW) method [30]. The U value for Ce 4f state was set as 5.0 eV using DFT+U method [31,32]. Convergence criterion for structure optimization was the maximum force on each atom <0.05 eV/Å and the energy cutoff was set as 400 eV DFT The 2 × 4 c(2 × 2) CeO2 (111) surface with six atomic layers was cleaved from cubic CeO2. The vacuum layer between plates was 15 Å and used a 2 × 2 × 1 k-point. During structure optimization, the adsorbates and top three layers were relaxed while bottom three layers were fixed. CI-NEB method was used to roughly estimate the transition states prior to precisely searching by Dimer method [33,34]. Adsorption energies were calculated by the equation of Eads(X)=EX/surf-EX-Esurf, where EX/surf, EX and Esurf are the calculated energies of the optimized adsorbate/surface system, the adsorbate X and the clean surface, respectively. The dispersion correction was conducted with the Grimme-D3 method [35]. Microkinetic analysis was carried out using the CATKINAS procedure [23]. The reaction temperatures were set as 500 K ∼ 900 K, the partial pressure of each reactant and the number of active sites were set the same as experimental conditions [1,36] (The feed gas had 0.1 %C3H8, 5 % O2 balanced with Ar at a total flow rate of 100 mL/min, 50 mg catalyst with Pt loading amount of 0.1 wt%). Kinetic calculation details were shown in the supplementary note section in Supporting Information. The energy barriers of adsorption and desorption processes were treated by collision theory (CT) [37,38]. 3 Results and discussions The first step of C3H8 oxidation reaction was C3H8 adsorbing on Pt sites by dissociating one H [20,39]. Afterwards, the bridge adsorption of C3H8 was designed (Fig. S1a). It can be seen that C3H8 only adsorbed on Pt site and was far from CeO2 surface after relaxation (Fig. S1a). Furthermore, oxygen vacancies (Ov) are usually present on CeO2 surface, and they are easily filled by O2 [1]. Hence, we also designed the bridge adsorption of C3H8 with Ov (Fig. S1b). After relaxation, C3H8 remained individually adsorbing on Pt site and kept off CeO2 surface (Fig. S1b). These results indicated that C3H8 tends to atop adsorb on Pt dimer. For Pt ensemble, the structure of C3H8 bridging onto several Pt atoms was established (Fig. S2). C3H8 was also found to individually adsorb on one Pt site after relaxation (Fig. S2), illustrating that C3H8 is prone to atop adsorb on Pt ensemble. Accordingly, the atop adsorption structures of C3H8 on Pt dimer and Pt ensemble were preferentially chosen as calculation models, and the structures after relaxation are respectively shown in Fig. S3a and S3b. Fig. S4 respectively displayed the most stable structures of C3H8 (Fig. S4a) and O2 (Fig. S4b) adsorbing on Pt2 CeO2 and Pt13 CeO2 after relaxation. The design of each elementary step of C3H8 oxidation reaction pathway followed two principles: 1) bonding and bond-breaking processes between two atoms should take place in a suitable spatial distance; 2) choosing the most stable structure when several candidates occurred for a certain reaction step. Besides, the issue of intermediates individually adsorbing and co-adsorbing on one Pt site was considered during designing reaction steps. Table 1 and Table 2 summarized all the elementary reaction steps of C3H8 oxidation process on Pt2 CeO2 and Pt13 CeO2, respectively. The reaction type, enthalpy change of each step and energy barriers of some steps were also exhibited. These elementary steps included six reaction types: dehydrogenation, adsorption, diffusion, migration, desorption and cracking, which were denoted as dehydr., adsorb., diffu., migra., desorb. and cracking, respectively. Note that the energy barriers of adsorption, desorption and diffusion steps were treated on the basis of their corresponding thermodynamics. When these steps were exothermic, the actual energy barriers were initially set as zero, while those of endothermic steps were initially set as the same values of corresponding enthalpy changes, as shown in Table 1 and Table 2. Table S1 and Table S2 showed the relaxed structure of each intermediate on Pt2 CeO2 and Pt13 CeO2, respectively. According to Table 1, the total reaction on Pt dimer is C3H8 + 5O2 → 3CO2 + 4H2O, and C3H8 was completely decomposed into CO2 and H2O. While on Pt ensemble, the total reaction is C3H8 + 4O2 → CO2 + 2CO + 4H2O, CO appeared as one of the products besides CO2 and H2O (Table 2). It needs to be illustrated that CO can be further oxidized to CO2, which had been thoroughly discussed by many studies [40–42]. Thus, the CO oxidation process will not be investigated here. In addition, the energy barrier of step19 (CH2OOCHOCH3*=CHOHOCHOCH3*, namely the migration of H on C) in Table 1 showed the highest value of 2.04 eV for C3H8 oxidation on Pt2 CeO2. While that was 1.04 eV for C3H8 oxidation on Pt13 CeO2 (Table 2), corresponding to step 42 (CH-OO*=COH-O*, namely C bonding with O). As a result, the energy barrier for C3H8 oxidation on Pt dimer is higher than that on Pt ensemble. To further reveal the rate-determining steps of C3H8 oxidation reaction and the key intermediates which significantly affect reactivity, the microkinetic analyses were conducted using the CATKINAS procedure [23]. Herein, the energy barriers of adsorption steps, desorption steps and the reaction steps of individually adsorbing species were treated by collision theory (CT) [37,38]. To be honest, the energy barrier of the adsorption and desorption process is generally difficult to estimate. A more accurate method is to use constraint MD to obtain it, which costs lots of time. In general, mobile model or immobile model is used to handle the estimation, but it can also be overestimated or underestimated. It should be noted that Collision Theory serves the purpose of obtaining meaningful pre-exponential factors to kinetic rate constants of the elementary steps, but not energetics, which must be obtained from experimental data. DFT does indeed provide energetics from simulations, but the values are subject to the uncertainties of which the basis set and functional of GGA-PBE are being applied. However, the use of the HSEO6 functional has shown closer agreement with experimental enthalpy values for CeO2 support [43,44]. The microkinetic analysis results of C3H8 oxidation on Pt2 CeO2 and Pt13 CeO2 are shown in Fig. 1 and Fig. 2 , respectively. Fig. 1a and 2a displayed the calculated turnover frequency (TOF) of C3H8 oxidation reaction on Pt dimer and Pt ensemble, respectively. The TOF difference between Pt dimer and Pt ensemble sharply increased from one to seven orders of magnitude with elevated temperatures. Consequently, Pt nanoparticles exhibited better C3H8 oxidation activity than Pt clusters, which is in line with the conclusion of Jeong et al. [17]. Fig. 1b displayed the degree of rate control (DRC) of key steps on Pt dimer. It is clear that step 19 (CH2OOCHOCH3*=CHOHOCHOCH3*) was the rate-determining step of C3H8 oxidation regardless of the temperatures, maybe due to its highest energy barrier among the whole reaction steps. The DRC of key intermediates is shown in Fig. 1c. The DRC value of CH2CHOCH3* was close to −1, indicating too stable adsorption of this intermediate on active sites, which might significantly limit C3H8 oxidation rate. The coverages of key intermediates were also calculated, as shown in Fig. 1d. The coverage of CH2CHOCH3* approached to 1, suggesting that it occupied almost all active sites, attributed to its stable adsorption as illustrated in Fig. 1c. Similarly, the DRC of key steps on Pt ensemble is shown in Fig. 2b. Step 40 (CO*=*+CO(g)) was the rate-determining step at the temperatures low than 800 K, it changed to other steps with elevated temperatures, indicating that CO* tends to spontaneously desorb at high temperatures. Additionally, the DRC of key intermediates is shown in Fig. 2c. The DRC value of CO* sharply increased at the temperatures high than 700 K, suggesting that its limiting affect greatly weakened at high temperatures, which was attributed to its rapid desorption as illustrated in Fig. 2b. Of course, the coverage of CO* also declined with elevated temperatures as shown in Fig. 2d. For Pt2 CeO2 system, the coverage of CH2CHOCH3* approached to 1 regardless of the temperatures from 500 K ∼ 900 K (Fig. 1d), suggesting that it occupied almost all active sites. While for Pt13 CeO2 system, the desorbing of CO* was rate-limiting step (Fig. 2b), and above 800 K, CO* was not the prominent species that limited reaction rate (Fig. 2c). Of course, the coverage of CO* at high temperatures still shared a large value, but a slight decrease can be observed than that at lower temperatures (Fig. 2d). Thus it is concluded that a relative higher CO* coverage could create a good balance between CO adsorption and desorption as well as brought a good activity at high temperatures. In summary, both theoretical and experimental results demonstrated that Pt nanoparticles showed remarkably superior C3H8 oxidation activity than Pt clusters on CeO2 surface. By microkinetic analyses, it is concluded that CH2CHOCH3* excessively occupied active sites, greatly limiting the C3H8 oxidation activity on Pt clusters; while on Pt nanoparticles, CO* was prone to spontaneously desorb at high temperatures and vacated active sites for other intermediates, contributing to improve total reaction rate. Consequently, the reactivity can be enhanced by properly reducing adsorption energies of key intermediates and controlling their coverages. The optimal C3H8 oxidation reaction pathway on Pt2 CeO2 was determined by microkinetic analysis based on the activity contribution namely TOF value of every possible step, its reaction steps and corresponding kinetic data at 600 K (the temperature of C3H8 starting conversion) were summarized in Table 3 . The sequence numbers of reaction steps shown in the first column in Table 3 were consistent with those in Table 1. The rate constant k of surface reaction was calculated using transition state theory (TST), while it was treated by collision theory (CT) [37,38] in adsorption and desorption processes. At the reaction temperature of 750 K, the rates of all steps increased about 2 orders of magnitude (Table S3). Fig. 3 and Fig. S5 displayed the energy profiles of optimal C3H8 oxidation reaction pathway on Pt2 CeO2 at 600 K and 750 K, respectively. Table 4 displayed the optimal C3H8 oxidation reaction pathway on Pt13 CeO2 and corresponding kinetic data at 600 K. The sequence numbers of reaction steps shown in the first column in Table 4 were the same as those in Table 2. The rates of all steps increased about 5 orders of magnitude at 750 K (Table S4). By comparation, it can be concluded that the reaction rate on Pt nanoparticles increased much more prominently than that on Pt clusters with elevated temperatures. Besides, the energy barriers of some steps would be changed under different reaction temperatures during microkinetic calculations for C3H8 oxidation both on Pt2 CeO2 and Pt13 CeO2, as shown in Table S5 and Table S6. We have also listed the Ea and TOF values in this work and experimental data (Table S7), the calculated TOF values are within two orders of magnitude difference comparing with those of experimental data, for that DFT-related deviations of adsorption and transition state energies of 0.1–0.2 eV can lead to TOF offsets of 1 or 2 orders of magnitude. The energy profiles of optimal C3H8 oxidation reaction pathway on Pt13 CeO2 at 600 K and 750 K are shown in Fig. 4 and Fig. S6, respectively. Accordingly, the mechanisms are different for O2 participating in the C3H8 oxidation process on Pt species with different sizes; there are abundant sites on Pt nanoparticles to anchor O2 species and proceed with other intermediates, while the lack of adsorbing sites on Pt clusters makes O2 have to react with the intermediates directly. The electronic properties of supported Pt species could be crucial in determining the reaction activity [45], thus the evolution of Pt mean Bader charge along the optimal C3H8 oxidation reaction pathway on Pt2 CeO2 and Pt13 CeO2 were calculated and the results are shown in Fig. S7 and Fig. S8, respectively. It can be found that the initial Pt mean Bader charge of Pt2 and Pt13 are almost the same. However, different evolution behaviors appeared during C3H8 oxidation; the valence states of Pt all increased and up to maximum 0.60 |e| for Pt2 CeO2, while most step increased and up to only maximum 0.03 |e| for Pt13 CeO2. As a result, Pt13 could keep its near metal state on the whole reaction process and displayed superior activity than that of Pt2. Fig. 5 a displayed the C3H8 decomposing process on Pt2 CeO2. C3H8 started to adsorb on Pt dimer by dissociating one H and then reacted with O2, which led to gradual desorption of H2O. Next, CO coupling caused CC bond breaking and generated CHOH* and OCOHCH3*. CHOH* removed H2O and then reacted with O2 to remove CO2, while OCOHCH3* reacted with O2 to remove H2O and cracked into COO* and CHOH*. COO* migrated to form CO2* then desorbed, while CHOH* reacted with O2 to decompose into CO2 and H2O. Simultaneously, the C3H8 decomposing process on Pt13 CeO2 is shown in Fig. 5b. First, C3H8 removed one H to adsorb on Pt ensemble and then reacted with O2 to remove H2O and formed CHCCH2*. Afterwards, CHCCH2* further reacted with O2 caused CO coupling, which broke CC bond to form CH2CO*. CH2CO* removed H2O and then reacted with O2 to generate CHCO2*, while CHO* further combined with CHCO2* to remove CO which generated CO* and CHOH*. CO* directly desorbed, while CHOH* removed H2O and combined with dissociated O* to form CO2* then desorbed. In summary, the adsorption and dissociation of O2 are key steps which contribute to promote C3H8 combustion. Because of more Pt sites on the surface of Pt ensemble to adsorb O2, C3H8 can react with sufficient activated O, which results in a faster decomposition rate on Pt nanoparticles than that on Pt clusters. 4 Conclusions The structures of Pt2 dimer and Pt13 ensemble individually adsorbing on CeO2 (111) were established to represent the catalyst models with active sites of Pt clusters and Pt nanoparticles, respectively, to investigate the propane oxidation reaction mechanisms on Pt-CeO2 catalysts with different particle sizes. Based on two principles of the atoms reacting in a proper spatial distance and ensuring the lowest energy of product intermediate, the optimal C3H8 oxidation reaction steps were determined by DFT calculations and microkinetic analyses. It was found that the mechanisms are different for O2 participating in the C3H8 oxidation process on Pt species with different sizes; there are abundant sites on Pt nanoparticles to anchor O2 species and proceed with other intermediates, while the lack of adsorbing sites on Pt clusters makes O2 have to react with the intermediates directly. The results of microkinetic analyses further revealed that CH2CHOCH3* excessively occupied active sites, greatly limiting the C3H8 oxidation activity on Pt clusters; while on Pt nanoparticles, CO* was prone to spontaneously desorb at high temperatures and vacated active sites for other intermediates, contributing to improve total reaction rate. Accordingly, properly reducing the adsorption energies of key intermediates and controlling their coverages contribute to enhance the reactivity of C3H8 oxidation. coredata.dc:description: Elucidating the reaction mechanism for large molecule like C3H8 species remains challenging, and the performances determined by metals’ sizes are still in heavily debate. In this work, we figured out the optimal C3H8 oxidation reaction pathway on Pt-CeO2 structure by density functional theory (DFT) calculations and microkinetic analysis, and revealed that O2 participating in C3H8 oxidation showed different paths with different Pt sizes. Microkinetic results further revealed that CH2CHOCH3* excessively occupying active sites dramatically limited C3H8 oxidation performance on Pt clusters, while the superior activity on Pt nanoparticles was attributed to rapid desorption of CO* at high temperatures.
